stem: A newborn is being evaluated for a suspected congenital heart defect. Highlight the findings that are characteristic of coarctation of the aorta.
passage: The nurse is performing a newborn assessment. Vital signs show a [blood pressure of 94/62 mmHg in the right arm] and [64/42 mmHg in the right leg]. The nurse notes that the [brachial and radial pulses are full and bounding], while the [femoral and pedal pulses are weak and difficult to palpate]. The nurse observes [skin that is pale and cool in the lower extremities]. Upon auscultation, a [systolic murmur is heard best at the left infraclavicular area] and [radiates to the back]. The newborn has [mild tachypnea] at 62 breaths/min. When the infant cries, the [upper body appears flushed] while the [lower body remains pale].

rationale.correct: Coarctation of the aorta (CoA) involves a narrowing of the aortic lumen, typically near the ductus arteriosus. This obstruction increases afterload proximal to the narrowing, leading to hypertension and bounding pulses in the upper extremities. Distal to the coarctation, blood flow is reduced, resulting in hypotension, weak or absent pulses, and cool, pale skin in the lower extremities. The increased pressure proximal to the narrowing can cause a systolic murmur, often heard best at the left infraclavicular area and radiating to the back due to turbulent blood flow. Tachypnea may occur as the body attempts to compensate for decreased oxygen delivery to tissues. Differential perfusion (flushed upper body, pale lower body) is a classic sign, reflecting the disparity in blood flow.
incorrect: The fact that the nurse is performing a newborn assessment is the context.
rationale.clinicalPearls: A key clinical pearl is to always assess blood pressure in all four extremities during newborn assessments to screen for CoA. A difference of >10 mmHg between upper and lower extremity systolic BP is highly suggestive of CoA. Early detection and intervention are crucial to prevent complications such as heart failure and stroke.
rationale.questionTrap: Upper Body = Bounding/High BP. Lower Body = Weak/Low BP. Don't be misled by normal respiratory rate; tachypnea indicates compensation.

reviewUnits.heading: Coarctation Assessment
reviewUnits.body: Look for BP and pulse discrepancies between upper and lower extremities. Assess skin color and temperature differences. Auscultate for murmurs, especially in the back.

answerBreakdown.label: Critical Cues
answerBreakdown.content: The identified evidence represents objective clinical markers of physiological instability indicative of coarctation of the aorta.

mnemonic.title: CoA-BP
mnemonic.expansion: Coarctation of Aorta - Blood Pressure (Upper > Lower)

sbar.situation: 0800: Newborn being evaluated for suspected coarctation of the aorta (CoA).
sbar.background: CoA is a congenital heart defect involving narrowing of the aorta, obstructing blood flow to the lower body. This increases afterload proximal to the narrowing.
sbar.assessment: 0805: Newborn exhibits BP 94/62 mmHg (right arm), 64/42 mmHg (right leg); bounding brachial/radial pulses, weak/difficult to palpate femoral/pedal pulses; pale, cool skin (lower extremities); systolic murmur (left infraclavicular area, radiating to back); mild tachypnea (62 breaths/min); flushed upper body, pale lower body when crying.
sbar.recommendation: 0810: Cardiology consult STAT for echocardiogram to confirm CoA diagnosis. Initiate prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) infusion to maintain ductal patency and improve lower body perfusion. Monitor vital signs, oxygen saturation, and urine output closely. Prepare family for potential surgical intervention or cardiac catheterization.
